ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved in my writing Hebrew.

I enjoyed the opportunity to read different forms and styles of writing in Hebrew, from plays to poetry to journalism and short stories. In crafting my own writing assignments in the different genres I feel like I expanded my skills in both Hebrew and creative writing.
Hebrew reading and comprehension greatly improved. My creative writing skills in hebrew improved as well.

You learn how to read and write (in Hebrew) in a few genres of creative writing, such as dramatic monologues, poetry, newspaper articles, etc. You also develop the skills to discuss such genres critically and to be able to give constructive feedback and advice to peers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength- the assignments
Weakness - discussions could have been better

There is a lot of material to engage with in this course, which can be challenging if you are a less confident or advanced reader of Hebrew. The most difficult part was completing the same volume of reading between Monday and Wednesday that we were assigned between Wednesday and Monday - I think reducing the reading load during the week would be my main recommendation for an improvement.

The best part of the class was the workshop element - I enjoyed sharing my work and getting feedback from my classmates, as well as hearing their writing and giving my own feedback in return. It's a great way to get exposed to other styles of writing in Hebrew, and also practice a different kind of Hebrew conversation than you find in other classes.

Strengths: workshopping, dynamic learning style, ability to write creatively in different mediums 
Weaknesses: no weaknesses stand out to me other than there being a lot of work but it was a great course.

The course setting and structure is a major strength. Being quite small made it easy to connect with peers and with the professor (who is also incredible!). The course is structured such that there are a few weeks of reading, then a week of writing, and then a week of presenting/discussing. This structure was very helpful as it kept everything moving at a set pace and expectations were very clear. Feedback was also excellent. The only slight weakness was some of the homework didn't always feel particularly helpful. But overall, an amazing course!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! It was very intellectually challenging and rigorous. Also super interesting.

I absolutely would recommend this class, particularly if you enjoy literature courses! You don't need prior experience in creative writing, although if you are an avid creative writer you do get the option to modify and translate a piece you've written in a different language to fit the assignment so I imagine that could be a timesaver.
Yes definitely it is a great Hebrew class with opportunities to read a lot and work on creative writing in hebrew.

Yes, absolutely! This class was often the highlight of my day/week. Discussions were always great, and it was just fun. There didn't seem to be a lot of pressure, yet by the end my Hebrew improved significantly, and I feel like I got so much out of this class.
